verses.text: In my distress I called to the Lord, and He answered me.
verses.comment: This verse highlights the Lord's readiness to respond to those who call on Him in trouble. The structure underscores the intimacy of prayer, prefiguring Christ's own prayers in distress (Hebrews 5:7).

verses.text: Deliver my soul, Lord, from lying lips, from a deceitful tongue.
verses.comment: The psalmist prays for deliverance not from physical danger but from slander and false accusation. This echoes the need for truth, a virtue Christ exemplified (John 14:6), and a theme repeated in James 3:5-10 regarding the power of the tongue.

verses.text: What shall be given to you, and what more shall be done to you, deceitful tongue?
verses.comment: A rhetorical question that underscores the seriousness of bearing false witness. The tongue's destruction is foreshadowed, a just retribution for sin as explained in Romans 6:23—the wages of sin is death.

verses.text: Sharp arrows of a warrior, with glowing coals of the broom tree!
verses.comment: Divine retribution is depicted vividly. Arrows and burning coals reflect God's justice poured out upon the wicked (cf. Ephesians 6:16—imagery of spiritual warfare). Early Christian interpreters saw in this a warning about spiritual consequences for those who prefer falsehood over God's truth.

verses.text: Woe to me, that I sojourn in Meshech, that I dwell among the tents of Kedar!
verses.comment: Meshech and Kedar represent distant peoples, often viewed as hostile or pagan neighbors. The psalmist laments spiritual alienation. Christians throughout history have interpreted this as a longing for our true home, echoing Hebrews 13:14—'For here we have no lasting city'.

verses.text: My soul has dwelt too long with those who hate peace.
verses.comment: Here, the suffering of living among the unfaithful is stressed. Spiritually, it reflects the Church’s journey through a world often opposed to God's peace. It foreshadows Christ, the Prince of Peace (Isaiah 9:6; John 14:27), whose followers are also called to persevere amid opposition.

verses.text: I am for peace, but when I speak, they are for war.
verses.comment: Though the psalmist seeks peace, he encounters hostility. This condition mirrors that of Christ, who is rejected despite bringing reconciliation (cf. John 1:11; Romans 5:10-11). The call to be a peacemaker finds deep resonance here, linking the psalmist’s plight to the Beatitudes.
